abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated unsatisfactory, and
            sustainability is unlikely. Consistent with the findings of
            the Quality Assurance Group, the project failed to achieve
            most of its major objectives, largely because the Nepal
            Water Supply Corporation was subject to tight government
            controls, with detrimental turnover at the board, and senior
            management, thus the objective of strengthening
            institutional capability was not met. Neither were the
            physical objectives by closing time. Among the lessons drawn
            from the project, it is specified that the Bank's
            failure to identify key weaknesses, and to act decisively to
            relieve adversity, contributed to the negative results. But
            the single most failure of both the Bank, and Government,
            was the lack of institutional autonomy, needed to reduce
            political interference in management practices. Investment
            sequencing in physical infrastructure, and technical
            assistance should be measurable, and conditional to the
            achievement of agreed institutional performance, an approach
            being followed in sector dialogues. Furthermore, procurement
            impaired project outcomes, due to consistent delays,
            difficulties in preparing pre-qualification documents, and,
            weak evaluating criteria. However, the reduction in water
            losses proved successful in the management of unaccounted
            for water, but commitment is needed for a lasting leak
            detection capacity.
